NoteLiteral.En:
For whom?
This challenge is open to PhD students from all fields.

Admission requirements
You must upload a confirmation of your PhD student status from your home university
You must fill inn all the fields in the form linked under the application information section. This information is required to complete the admission process at University of Stavanger.

Admission process
We process applications toward the end of the application period. If your application is accepted, you will receive an offer sent to your ECIU email address.
Please remember to check your ECIU email and spam folder regularly, and note that you have 7 days to accept the offer.

Description.En: This transdisciplinary course will put doctoral fellow candidates at the front of knowledge, and with participatory research skills for research based on empathy, compassion and meaning. We offer this course in the believe that universities are not only to prepare doctoral candidates on how to do research, but to prepare scholars to do research that is implemented in ways that helps others and contributes to the better good in the world, and in accordance to the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

NoteLiteral.En: Upon course completion, the candidate has advanced theoretical knowledge about the contributions from different traditions in the study of empathy, compassion and meaning; contributes significant to the development and documentation of new research-based knowledge and practices in empathy, compassion, and meaning.

Upon course completion, the candidate can challenge established knowledge and practices in the fields of empathy, compassion and meaning; plan and conduct research that addresses issues of empathy, compassion and meaning in their projects in a reflective way; handle complex issues about the impact that our own emotions and values, as well as those of others, have in mental health and well-being.

After completing the course, the candidate should be able to identify and critically evaluate relevant ethical dilemmas around empathy, compassion and meaning in research, as well as respond to these with scholarly integrity; assess the need for, as well as initiate and practice transdisciplinary and innovative collaborations in research based on the principles of empathy, compassion and meaning; critically reflect about the epistemological and ontological implications of different understandings of empathy, compassion and meaning.

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
**For whom?**

This challenge is open to PhD students from all fields, as well as staff holding a PhD.

**When?**

The course is conducted on campus at University of Stavanger from 25-29 August 2025. Please note that all students must attend the full week.

There will be an online introduction of the challenge on 18 August.

**Challenge structure:**

Candidates draft a case based on their project concerning their participants, users, their collaborator partners or team, and analyze it through the angles of empathy, compassion, and meaning theories.

Please see a link to the course here: [Empathy, Compassion and Meaning: Theory and participatory approaches](https://www.uis.no/en/course/PHD304_1)

**Exams and assessment**

The course will be assessed via a 4000 words +/- 10% (excluding references) paper that includes:

- A case formulation related to their PhD project, where empathy, compassion and meaning are at stake. This is to include a description of  the possibilities and challenges of  implementing theories within empathy, compassion and meaning in their project.
- An analysis of how the challenges identified in the case will be addressed to ensure that the people involved can experience trust, inclusivity, and perceive empathy, compassion and meaning. This formulation will be solution-oriented and provide, if applicable, perspectives on user-involvement.
- A reflexivity statement where the candidate critically reflects upon the possibilities and limits of empathy, compassion and meaning towards the challenges portrayed in the case.

The assessment is graded on a pass/not pass basis and must be completed within five weeks after the course has finished (Friday 3 October 2025).  

**Funding to travel?**

Please contact your local/home university to check out the possibility to apply for funding for the travel and stay (mobility support). There might be an early deadline for this, so check this out as soon as you can.

**Housing and travel**

Due to the difficult housing situation in Stavanger, UiS cannot provide accommodation for shortterm international students. Therefore, you will have to find housing on the private market.

Please note that you are responsible for organizing your own travel.

This transdisciplinary course will put doctoral fellow candidates at the front of knowledge, and with participatory research skills for research based on empathy, compassion and meaning. We offer this course in the believe that universities are not only to prepare doctoral candidates on how to do research, but to prepare scholars to do research that is implemented in ways that helps others and contributes to the better good in the world, and in accordance to the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

**For whom?**

This challenge is open to PhD students from all fields, as well as staff holding a PhD.

**Admission requirements**

- You must upload a confirmation of your PhD student status from your home university, or documentation showing your completed PhD.
- You must fill inn all the fields in this form: [personal information registration](https://nettskjema.no/a/479632). This information is required to complete the admission process at University of Stavanger.

**Admission process**

We process applications throughout the application period. If your application is accepted, you will receive an offer sent to your ECIU email address.

Please remember to check your ECIU email and spam folder regularly, and note that you have 7 days to accept the offer.
